items: Learn basic Linux commands for navigation and file management
Practice moving around directories and viewing files
Become confident using the terminal for simple tasks

sections.heading: Basic Commands to Get Started
rows: Print working directory (shows your current location)
List files and folders in the current directory
Go back to the previous directory
Show a list of previously typed commands

sections.text: Linux commands are case-sensitive. Always type them exactly.

sections.heading: Practice
steps: List the files in your current directory: ls
Navigate into a folder (e.g., Documents): cd Documents
Go back to the previous directory: cd ..

sections.text: Extra Practice: Try combining commands. For example: cd Documents && ls - This moves into the Documents folder and lists its files immediately.

sections.heading: Key Terms
rows: A container for files and other directories
Location of a file or folder in the file system
Instruction you type into the terminal

sections.text: Using just a few commands, you can fully navigate your Linux system without ever touching a mouse!

bullets: Basic commands like pwd, ls, cd, clear, and history are essential for navigating and exploring Linux.
Practice using these commands to feel confident in the terminal.
Mastering these basics is the first step to powerful Linux skills.
